question: On þissum dagum #### micel þegen ferde eft to Englalande - On this day the mighty thane went again to England
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'se' because it is tied to the subject 'þegen'

question: Se biscop grete #### cyning — The abbot greets the king
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þone' because it is tied to 'cyning' which is directly receiving the action of the verb 'grete'

question: In #### cyninges tune — In the town of the king
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to 'cyning' which has the genitive singular 'es' ending

question: Se cyning ferþ to #### tune — The king goes to the town
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to 'tun' which has the dative singular 'e' ending

question: #### biscopas geaf þone stan to þaem þegne — The bishops gave the stone to the thane
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the subject 'biscop' which has the plural 'as' ending

question: Se cyning ond seo cwen grete #### biscopas — The king and the queen greet the bishops
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to 'biscop' which has the plural 'as' ending and is the direct recipient of the verb 'grete'

question: #### wicinga cyning wolde þæt þa Deniscan ricsoden ofer Englalande - The king of vikings willed that the Danes ruled over England
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to 'wicing' which has the genetive plural ending 'a'

question: Se geaf þa garas to #### þegnum — He gave the spear to the thanes
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to 'þegnum' which has the dative plural 'um' ending

question: #### biscop wæs halig and eaþmod - The bishop was holy and humble
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'se' because it is tied to the subject 'biscop'

question: Se þegen sloh #### biscop in þæm tune genemed Stanford — The thane slew the bishop in the town called Stamford
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þone' because it is tied to 'biscop' which is directly receiving the action of the verb 'sloh'

question: Ða bearn #### cyninges beoþ wis and eaþmod - The children of the king are wise and humble
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to 'cyning' which has the genitive singular 'es' ending

question: On þissum geare sende he þone ealdan biscop Wulfstan to #### stede þe genemened Readingum - On this year he sent the old Bishop Wulfstan to the place that was called Reading
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to 'stede'. While 'stede' already ends in an e, making it hard to tell the case, it is after the preposition 'to' and indirectly receiving the action which makes it dative

question: #### biscopas comon fram þæm tunum hetum Londenum ond Readingum — The bishops came from the towns called London and Reading
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the subject 'biscop' which has the plural 'as' ending

question: Gaþ! Fliemaþ #### Englas and timbriaþ fela tuna on hiera landum - Go! Banish the English and build many towns on their land
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to 'Englas' which has the plural 'as' ending and is the direct recipient of the verb 'fliemaþ'

question: Eall #### biscopa preostas ferde to þæm halige stede mid him — All the bishops’ priests went to the holy place with them
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to 'biscopa' which has the genetive plural ending 'a'

question: He cwæð þæt he bude on #### landum norþweardum wiþ þa Westsæ - He said that he lived in the lands northward along the west sea
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to 'land' which has the dative plural 'um' ending

question: Giet wæs #### cyning Aelfred geong - Still, the king Alfred was young
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'se' because it is tied to the subject 'cyning'

question: Ælfric geaf #### æþeling drync - Aelfric gave the prince a drink
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þone' because it is tied to 'æþeling' which is directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf'

question: He geaf #### æþelinges begas to þære cwene - He gave the prince's rings to the queen
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to 'æþeling' which has the genitive singular 'es' ending

question: Se abbot com fram #### beorgum - The abbot came from the mountains
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to 'beorg' which has the dative plural 'um' ending

question: #### scip sceal genægled - The ship must be nailed
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the subject 'scip'

question: #### wif wæs gehæled of ðam wite - The woman was healed of the disease
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the subject 'wif'

question: #### bearn is min dohtor - The child is my daughter
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the subject 'bearn'

question: Gif #### word sind soþ - If the words are true
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'word'

question: #### scipu ferde to þæm tune - The ships went to the town
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'scipu'

question: #### godu fram Egiptum landum beoþ fremede godu - The gods from Egypt are strange gods
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'godu'

question: He spræc to #### wif - He spoke to the woman
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the singular direct object 'wif'

question: Se preost gebletsade #### scip - The priest blessed the ship
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the singular direct object 'scip'

question: Se cyning geaf #### scip to his suna - The king gave the ship to his son
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæt' because it is tied to the singular direct object 'scip'

question: He wolde geseean #### godu - He wanted to visit the gods
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural direct object 'godu'

question: Se mann seah #### wif - The man saw the women
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural direct object 'wif'

question: Ðæt wæron #### erestan scipu Deniscra manna the Angelcynnes land geseah - Those were the first ships of Danish men the English people's land saw
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural direct object 'scipu'

question: #### scipes mæst geburnen - The ship's mast burned
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to the possessive 'scipes'

question: He geaf #### wifes boc to þæm biscop - He gave the woman's book to the bishop
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to the possessive 'wifes'

question: #### fremede godes preost bædon to his gode - The strange god's priest prayed to his god
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæs' because it is tied to the possessive 'godes'

question: On þis dæg, com #### hæthenes goda wigan - On that day, the warriors of the heathen gods came
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'goda'

question: #### scipa menn com fram Denemearc - The crew of the ships came from Denmark
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'scipa'

question: He geaf #### bearna bec to his suna - He gave the childrens books to his son
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'bearna'

question: Seo cwen geaf þa boc to #### wife - The queen gave the book to the woman
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'wife'

question: Se cyning spræc to #### bearne - The king spoke to the child
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'bearne'

question: Ða menn ferde to #### scipe mid þæm sceattum - The men went to the ship with the treasure
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'scipe'

question: Heo geaf micel giefa to #### wifum - She gave many gifts to the women
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'wifum'

question: Se here ferde to #### scipum - The army went to the ships
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'scipum'

question: Se preost bædon to #### godum - The priest prayed to the gods
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the indirect object 'godum'

question: #### cwen ferþ to þæm beorgum - The queen goes to the mountains
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'seo' because it is tied to the subject 'cwen'

question: #### ceaster ne mæg beon behyd - The city cannot be hidden
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'seo' because it is tied to the subject 'ceaster'

question: #### giefu wæs swiþe geæhted - The gift was greatly prized
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'seo' because it is tied to the subject 'giefu'

question: #### cwena wæron hatene Marsepia and Lampida - The queens were called Marsepia and Lampida
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'cwena'

question: #### ceastra, Gleawanceaster, Cirenceaster and Baþanceaster, beoþ on ceastrum weallum beworhte - The cities, Gloucester, Cirencester and Bath, are walled towns
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'ceastra'

question: #### idesa sloh ða wundenlocc þone fēondsceaðan - The women slew the wavy-haired fiend
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the plural subject 'idesa'

question: Ælla and Cissa ymbsæton #### ceastre - Aella and Cissa beseiged the city
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the singular direct object 'ceastre'

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þa' because it is tied to the singular direct object 'cwen'

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þære' because it is tied to the possessive 'cwene'

question: #### ceastre ealdorman spræc mid þæm biscope - The city's elderman spoke with the bishop
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þære' because it is tied to the possessive 'ceastre'

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'cwena'

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'ceastra'

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þara' because it is tied to the plural possessive 'idesa'

question: Hie to #### cwene agefon him - They gave him up to the queen
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þære' because it is tied to the indirect object 'cwene'

question: Ða þegnas ferde to #### idese - The thanes went to the lady

explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þære' because it is tied to the indirect object 'ceastre'

question: Hlynn wearþ on #### ceastrum - A great cry arose in the cities
explanation: Here the demonstrative pronoun is 'þæm' because it is tied to the plural indirect object 'ceastrum'
